item.title: Notepad messing up
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

Jc22493:

Didn’t read the replies, but word wrap?

Christ you guys its called word wrap. You need to enable it on notepad (sometimes?). To do this click ‘Format’ --> ‘Word Wrap’

Hope it works for you but I suggest either notepad++ or an IDE.
[/quote]No, it’s not word wrap. It’s the (ASCII?) codes some IDE’s use that aren’t registered with Notepad.

You can use an IDE, or also WordPad will work (which comes with windows)[/quote]Nah it’s not word wrap; it’s how net beans formats newlines :S

Read full topic

item.title: Notepad messing up
item.dc:creator: @Kaex Kaex
item.description:
@Kaex wrote:

[quote=“ytuio9, post:1, topic:385423”][code=java]
import com.rs2.yz85.Server;
import com.rs2.yz85.io.PlayerLoader;
import com.rs2.yz85.model.*;
import com.rs2.yz85.util.Logger;

import java.io.IOException;
import java.util.Arrays;

/**

  • @author: Yz85Racer

  • Created by IntelliJ IDEA.
    */
    public class Main {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
    try {
    Server s = Server.getInstance(43594);
    s.start();
    s.setMaxPlayers(100);
    s.pluginPlayerLoader(new PlayerLoader() {
    public final void loadPlayer(Player plr) {
    plr.setAppearance(PlayerAppearance.instance(new int[] { 3, 19, 29, 35, 39, 44, 7, 8, 9, 5, 0 }));
    plr.setWaypoint(Waypoint.location(3254, 3420), true);
    int[] stats = new int[25];
    Arrays.fill(stats, 1);
    plr.setPlayerRights(PlayerRights.NORMAL_PLAYER);
    plr.setGender(PlayerGender.MALE);
    plr.setStats(stats);
    plr.setExps(stats);
    plr.setResponseCode((byte) 2);
    Logger.log(plr.getUsername() + " loaded.");
    }

             public final void savePlayer(Player plr) {
         }
     });
 } catch(IOException e) {
     e.printStackTrace();
 }

    }
    }

[/code]
This is what the actual code is. What it looks like on my comp is a different story, however.
Get ready for…

Any ideas? This seems to happen to newly downloaded files only, as the other .java files I had downloaded had the same “problem”. However, old Java files I had already created still work as normal…[/quote]

The reason that happens is because yz did hissource with netbeans, its stupid like that.
If he did it in Eclipse it would look fine.

Read full topic

item.title: Notepad messing up
item.dc:creator: @NewbieNewty Newty
item.description:
@NewbieNewty wrote:

Christ you guys its called word wrap. You need to enable it on notepad (sometimes?). To do this click ‘Format’ --> ‘Word Wrap’

Hope it works for you but I suggest either notepad++ or an IDE.

Read full topic

item.title: Notepad messing up
item.dc:creator: @Saphire1 Saphire`
item.description:
@Saphire1 wrote:

I found this works, my laptop had the exact problem as what you have and it only occurred the other day; try the following, these worked for me.

  • Backup a copy of c:\Windowd\notepad.exe
  • Disable System Restore
  • Replace notepad.exe
  • Enable System Restore

or

  • Create backup copy of c:\WINDOWS\notepad.exe
  • Change Explorer view options to show system files
  • Open folder C:\WINDOWS\ServicePackFiles\i386
  • Copy your notepad.exe
  • Open folder C:\WINDOWS\system32\dllcache
  • Copy your notepad.exe
  • Open folder C:\WINDOWS\system32
  • Copy your notepad.exe
  • Open folder C:\WINDOWS
  • Copy your notepad.exe

Read full topic

[/quote]
Then you need to learn to not hit buttons.[/quote]

item.title: Notepad messing up
item.dc:creator: @Wintercanon Wintercanon
item.description:
@Wintercanon wrote:

The *nix line breaks are different to Windows. Most applications have support for this, being so old Notepad doesn’t. It only happens to newly downloaded files because those files were written on a *nix OS. It is simple to get around this in Windows. Open the file in Wordpad and save it again. It will convert *nix line breaks to Windows line breaks. You will then be able to open it in Notepad.

Read full topic

item.title: Notepad messing up
item.dc:creator: @Svitkona Svitkona
item.description:
@Svitkona wrote:

import com.rs2.yz85.Server;
import com.rs2.yz85.io.PlayerLoader;
import com.rs2.yz85.model.*;
import com.rs2.yz85.util.Logger;

import java.io.IOException;
import java.util.Arrays;

/**
 * @author: Yz85Racer
 * Created by IntelliJ IDEA.
 */
public class Main {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        try {
            Server s = Server.getInstance(43594);
            s.start();
            s.setMaxPlayers(100);
            s.pluginPlayerLoader(new PlayerLoader() {
                public final void loadPlayer(Player plr) {
                    plr.setAppearance(PlayerAppearance.instance(new int[] { 3, 19, 29, 35, 39, 44, 7, 8, 9, 5, 0 }));
                    plr.setWaypoint(Waypoint.location(3254, 3420), true);
                    int[] stats = new int[25];
                    Arrays.fill(stats, 1);
                    plr.setPlayerRights(PlayerRights.NORMAL_PLAYER);
                    plr.setGender(PlayerGender.MALE);
                    plr.setStats(stats);
                    plr.setExps(stats);
                    plr.setResponseCode((byte) 2);
                    Logger.log(plr.getUsername() + " loaded.");
                }

                public final void savePlayer(Player plr) {
                }
            });
        } catch(IOException e) {
            e.printStackTrace();
        }
    }
}

This is what the actual code is. What it looks like on my comp is a different story, however.
Get ready for…

Any ideas? This seems to happen to newly downloaded files only, as the other .java files I had downloaded had the same “problem”. However, old Java files I had already created still work as normal…

Read full topic
